segments.text: Hey guys, welcome back to the show. Today we are going to be interviewing Julie Goldstein
about the issue of trans children. Now if you've watched the show before you'll know
that when it comes to trans kids, I just do not believe that children are old enough
or mature enough to be able to do something like determine their own gender. Julie, however,
disagrees with that and she actually reached out to me wanting to share her perspective.
As an activist, Julie is extremely well informed about the procedures and guidelines that
currently surround children transitioning. Regardless of how you or I might feel about
trans children, it's important to remember that the views that Julie holds are now what's
considered in many ways standard in Western medicine. In the medical, the psychiatric,
the psychological community right now, Julie's views are considered mainstream. Honestly,
a doctor is more likely to agree with her than with me. These are the opinions. These are
the viewpoints, the mentality that we are dealing with and I think it is so important
that we understand them. So with that being said, I am hugely thankful to Julie for being
willing to come on here and talk about these issues which I know are controversial. In any
case though, let's get on with the show. Hey Julie, thank you so much for coming on.
Oh, thanks for having me Lauren. I really appreciate it. Yeah, no problem. So you've
actually been on Stephen Crowder's show before and I think a lot of people who saw that episode
really enjoyed it, really enjoyed the conversation for people who maybe missed out on that and
aren't familiar with you, would you mind I guess giving a bit of your background, your
interests are that kind of thing? Sure, I'm an actress and voice over artist,
but I'm also a trans rights activist. I think what distinguishes me from other people is
I kind of like to talk to people about the data and I like to get other points of view.
I've never been on one of those people who's uncomfortable hearing a different point of
view. So it's easier to have conversations that way across the aisle, which I don't
think a lot of us are having anymore. And I think that's that's so great and that's
why I'm so happy to have you here today. What I was hoping we could talk about was specifically
the issue of trans children. That's something we've talked a lot about on my show. People
who have watched my episodes before know that when it comes to the issue of transitioning
and gender, I do think that you know, five, six, seven year olds, these children, these
children aren't able to maybe grasp all the complexities and nuance that revolve around
gender. I know that's not the point of view you have. And so I was hoping that we could
talk about that for people who maybe missed out on your conversation with Crowder because
I think you guys did touch upon this when he had you on. What are your views to that?
Transitioning and children, do you support it? Yes or no? And is there an age where you
think that a child would be too young to be able to self identify their own gender?
Well, I think the most important thing to understand is that when a child comes out
or they're diagnosed with gender dysphoria as a child as five, six years old, there's
nothing medical that is done. Any even puberty blockers require that the child be at Tanner
Stage 2, which usually takes place around nine to 11 depending on the child's development.
So even if a child is socially transitioning, let's say to be diagnosed with gender dysphoria,
it's basically the DSM-5 states that they have to have at least six months of significant
incompatibility with the gender they identify with and the gender they were born with, including
specifically an intense want to be the opposite gender persistence that they are the opposite
gender that they were assigned at birth. That's a very big change from the DSM-4 and one of
the biggest problems with the DSM-4 is that it conflated gender nonconformity with gender
dysphoria. So you would have children who let's say a girl is a tomboy or a boy just is a
feminine and unfortunately under the old gender identity disorder diagnosis prior to 2013,
they would fall under that diagnosis. Nowadays under the gender dysphoria diagnosis, they very
specifically have to have an intense want need that they are the gender they identify with and
that distinguishes them and that's the way that you can separate the gender nonconforming kids and
even once they get to that point and let's say they've been diagnosed with gender dysphoria and
they're five or six, all that really, all that's really done with these kids is a social transition
may be different clothes, different name, nothing that would ever be permanent. So these kids aren't
being locked into a path for the rest of their lives. They're actually monitored very closely
once they have the diagnosis, monitored of course medically to see how puberty is continuing and
then once they hit Tanner stage two, they can start making decisions about puberty blockers.
Usually it's around 13, 14 if they've had intense dysphoria and they've been monitored for their
entire life, then they would go on to hormones and surgery. Bottom surgery, I'm very specific in that
and it's the current standards that you have to be of age of medical consent in order to undergo
that type of surgery. But still puberty blockers themselves, you're still at an area where it's
reversible. There are specific cases that Norman Spak, Dr. Spak and Dr. Steensma himself, who is
the author of usually the most cited study on desistance where that 80% desistance rate comes in.
They notated and studied kids with gender dysphoria and in Dr. Steensma's study there were two kids
who discontinued puberty blockers and in Dr. Spak's there was one and all that happened is that they
continued puberty as normal. There were no irreversible effects. Well I'm glad you've kind of mentioned
that there is the issue of social transitioning and then medical procedures like the hormone blockers
and then surgery. But before we get into that, I do want to go over just the initial diagnosis of
gender dysphoria. So I think I have the current, I guess, criteria here. I believe there's eight
different things that they look for and if you have at least six of them, it can count as a
diagnosis of gender dysphoria. And you mentioned that it was different for the DSM IV, but I'm
looking at the list right now and I still see that a lot of the things, and this is I think where I'm
concerned and people like Deborah Sower are concerned, that seem to conflate perhaps gender
dysphoria with being gender nonconforming. You know, a girl who likes boys toys and things like that.
I still see things like a strong preference for wearing clothes typical of the opposite gender,
a strong preference for playmates of the other gender, a strong preference for the toys, games,
or activities stereotypically used or engaged in by the other gender. I still see them listed as
things that could contribute to a diagnosis of gender dysphoria. So I mean, I'm just kind of
wanting to know how you or someone who is in the profession of diagnosing them, how would they
distinguish between this? You know, let's say we have a five year old who is meeting a lot of
these criteria. And maybe once they even said that they, let's say, I'm not a girl and they like to
play with boys and boys clothes and stuff. If someone was in the medical profession, how would
they navigate navigate that? Because that's where it just seems a little bit arbitrary for me because
these are, I mean, these are very complex issues. And I just question a child's ability to not only
maybe understand their own feelings at the time at such a young age, but then to even
beyond that, express them coherently, if that makes sense. Yeah, well, there's a shorthand that
therapists who work with gender diverse and gender nonconforming and transgender kids use,
which is insistent, persistent, inconsistent. So basically children in order for them to meet
the diagnosis, especially under the DSM-5, they have to be insistent and adamant that they are the
gender that they identify with. And it's because they're monitored for so long, that's a feeling that,
again, insistent, consistent, persistent over time. And the way that at least Diane Ercifat,
who is one of the doctors at the Gender Clinic in San Francisco, what she does to distinguish,
she tries to distinguish if the kid is engaging, to see if they have a sense of it,
of sense of their own gender, they see if they are engaging in what's called either fantasy
play or serious work. So if they're just pretending to be, let's say, Elsa versus no, I'm a girl,
I want to wear the dress uniform for school and very much identify with the gender that they
identify with. But isn't, I guess, the concern that perhaps we are almost enforcing some of these
socialized gender norms? Well, here's where it gets a little confusing. I think it gets,
it's a little confusing in the sense that we use the term gender dysphoria. And I've said,
multiple times that I think that's a little misleading of a term because we conflate gender
with gender norms, gender, gender rules. And truthfully, especially under the DSM-5,
thankfully, it's very much a combination of gender and sex. So it very much specifically
has to also revolve around the uncomfortability with one's own body. Like anatomy, right? Exactly.
So if you listen to parents of trans kids, one I definitely want to point to is Debbie Jackson.
Listen to her story of her daughter Avery, and she'll specifically say that at first it started
with toys, it started with clothes, and she just brushed it off as, oh, he's just a feminist. And
then she started noticing that he was incredibly uncomfortable, or she was incredibly uncomfortable
with her anatomy, her penis. I'm not going to shy away from terms. Go for it, go for it.
So she noticed that, and she noticed that he was having, she was having a lot of distress over it.
And that's when she started doing research on what this possibly could be. There definitely
is a physical component. If the child is only having, only shows a preference for toys or things
of the opposite gender, that by itself isn't enough to constitute a diagnosis. And I think,
especially as kids get older, especially because Christina Olson, who does a lot of research with
trans kids, did a study showing that gender identity of kids who are diagnosed with gender dysphoria
have as deeply held an identity as there's this gender peers. So they identify just as much,
their identity is just as strong as their cisgender peers. So that rules out this idea of confusion,
that they're confused, or that they're conflating, liking female things with being female. They
have an understanding that that's separate from identity. Like all of these things, if making
it sound very, I guess, concrete, very empirical, which I think medical diagnoses should be. But you
mentioned the statistic earlier about how there have been several studies about this. But one
such study mentions that around 80% of children who display gender dysphoria when they're younger,
as they get older, do not end up being transgender or identifying as the opposite gender. There is a
maturation process with children and other, I guess, medical issues like borderline personality
disorder, these medical professionals, they're actually very hesitant, usually,
to diagnose minors with them because a lot of the symptoms happen to coincide with general
feelings of puberty, feeling loss, anxious on sure of themselves, all of these different feelings.
With that in mind, would that make you any more hesitant to support even something like a social
transition? Knowing that for a lot of maybe even most of these children who display gender dysphoria,
they will end up identifying later on as their natal sex?
No, for a couple different reasons. First of all, the study, the stinzma study, where the 80%
comes from, there are a couple different issues with it. First of all, it took the diagnosis for
gender identity disorder, which the problem there is that it did conflate gender nonconforming kids
with kids with gender dysphoria. So it didn't have that differentiation that we do now to get that
gender dysphoria diagnosis. So that immediately throws those out. The other thing is that stinzma
himself is very adamant about how it was that study that they did was not trying to measure or
cannot be used as a measure of desistance and persistence. What they were trying to do was see
what factors contributed to persistence and desistance. And actually, a lot of those,
a lot of what he found is what was used to change the standards from the DSM-4 to the DSM-5.
And he actually found that their persistence, starting around the age of 10 and subsequent years,
persistence, the persistence indicated that their cross gender preferences and behavior and their
gender identity remained stable, but that their dysphoric feelings intensified. So essentially,
their identity was still the same. They were still just as sure that they were the opposite sex,
but once puberty started, they became a lot more distressed. So that's definitely one thing that
I believe we see in kids that get that gender dysphoria diagnosis or move on to puberty blockers.
They are extremely distressed over the fact that their body is about to irreversibly change.
That, honestly, I can tell you from myself that is exactly what I experienced when I was that age.
As opposed to those who desisted, it decreased over that time. So those that are moving on to
the next step, we're very specifically seeing that they are distressed. As puberty starts,
they become more suicidal, do self-harm. Its depression really sets in and it really starts
to affect these kids' lives and their mood and their schoolwork. I can tell you from personal
experience again, that's exactly what happened to me. When I came out, it's because that was,
I was going through that at, I think it was like 11 or it was 12. That's a common experience.
And that's the other thing. One more point that I want to say is that back when Steensma was doing
his study, the typical way that kids like that were treated was not via affirmation. They were
being treated by items, treatment like what Ken Zucker did, which was more akin to what we now know
as conversion therapy. It was trying to get the child to stop having those behaviors. And unfortunately,
those techniques harm a child psychologically so much that you may think their
desisting, but what they're doing is they're just trying to please you because they know they're
not in a safe environment. And again, I tell you from personal experience, that is exactly what
happened with me, where I was put through conversion therapy and you just get it go into survival
mode. And that's what happened to a lot of these kids because of the fact that the desistent studies,
they weren't measuring, let's say 10 years in the future, they were measuring shortly thereafter.
And that's the point where they're starting to be a little more guarded about who they are
because they know that they're going to be punished for it. Well, that's actually, you know, in the
study, and I think it's the 2013, it's the Dutch study that you're referencing, because there have
been several studies done about persistence versus desistance. And all of them have found that a
majority do eventually desist. I personally would love to see even more studies done about this. I
don't think there's any such thing as too much data, especially when we're dealing with something
that is so important. We want to have follow ups. We want to know how these children are doing
10 years, 20 years down the line. I think they should also control for things like environmental
factors, whether they've kept up seeing therapists, peer groups and all of that stuff. So the study
does note that the degree to which you felt gender dysphoria when you were first diagnosed,
as well as your age when you were first diagnosed, were predictors of whether you would persist or
desist with your gender dysphoria. So if you're feeling it when you're five and you're diagnosed,
then you are less likely to persist than if you were diagnosed when you were 13, which to me
does make sense because I think when we're starting to get into those later years, you do develop a
stronger sense of your own gender identity. But I think ultimately, because there is this study,
and I would again, totally admit that there should be more work done on it, isn't that enough to
give you any sort of pause, especially like you mentioned, puberty blockers and things like that
aren't given to five year olds or anything like that. But you put out the number eight, nine,
even 10, I think a lot of people might believe, even if it's not permanent, that giving a child
those types of medications for something that may or may not persist into adulthood
is quite quite an extreme step. Are you, I guess, understanding of those concerns,
those people who might say even if you did end up transitioning, that it's better to wait.
The current diagnostic system is working. And the reason we know that is because yes, there are
detransitioners, but there has not been a single case of someone who was prescribed medical treatment,
either puberty blockers or hormone treatment, while under the age of consent, who has later
gone on to regret having had said access. Now that doesn't mean that they didn't desist. As I said,
there are two people in the Steensma study and one person in the Norman Spak study who
desist it, not necessarily desist it, they had a better understanding as the way they described it,
of their gender identity and found out that they didn't really identify with either or and ended up
being what they called genderqueer or just gender nonconforming. But even they will say that they
don't regret having gone through that process because they needed that pause and that time
to really understand themselves. So knowing that and knowing that it's been.
I guess you have to admit that this is a fairly new phenomenon, right? I mean, it's true that we
don't have all of these cases of people who when they were children, being given these hormones,
now saying that they regret it. But I think we're seeing more and more numbers of this
happening. So is there any part of you that does wonder what's going to happen in 10 years?
What's going to happen in in 15 years when these kids who were in a lot of ways, maybe the first
people to undergo this and you know this particular diagnosis and the treatment plans when they get
older? Do you think there's any chance of that happening? Maybe not now, but in the future?
Well, I mean, there's always a chance. I'm not going to say that there's no chance.
But the truth of the matter is I think it's a misconception that it's so new. puberty blockers
have actually been used on trans youth since the mid 90s and earlier for precocious puberty and
none of those kids became trans. But the important thing is that we actually are seeing the first
generation that was prescribed puberty blockers and went on to cross sex hormones and surgery.
They're actually not as young as you think. They're actually closer to their late 20s at this point.
I mean, you see the case of let's say Kim Petras, who is an international pop star at this moment.
You see the case of Nicole Maines, who's on Supergirl. You see jazz Jennings herself. I mean,
she's about to go to Harvard. These kids who were prescribed this treatment are actually thriving
in a world that is ever changing in front of them. So I think that speaks to the fact that
these treatments are lifesaving and it's necessary for these kids to live the best
lives that they can. Especially when I talk to parents of trans kids, it's apparent to me that
these kids are growing up in a world that was not available when I was growing up. And I see them
having a better world and a better life than they're, as we call them, transistors.
So I did want to bring up, I don't want to keep you all night, but I do want to bring up the issue
of what's rapid onset gender dysphoria. Now, this isn't like an official term or anything,
but it is the phrase that one study at least used to refer to the phenomenon of especially
young girls in certain peer groups and clusters, rapidly developing symptoms of gender dysphoria
and going on to at least want to transition. The survey, it has been criticized, of course,
and I'm not going to say it's perfect. Again, I would always say that more studies, more data is
better, but it is an interesting concept. They kind of hypothesize that in some ways gender
dysphoria acts as a social contagion. Similar to, you know, we see this with suicides and even self
harm among teen groups. They can be influenced by what their peers are doing. Do you think there's
anything to that? Because I think there's a big debate over how much of gender dysphoria is something
that's biological innate, maybe neurological versus socialized, right? I mean, ideally,
I would love it if there was like a brain scan and we could be sure. I think it would help a lot,
and it would also help to the solidify the, I guess, validity of people's identities who are
trans, right? Because there are a lot of people who say it's made up a fairy tale. I'm not there,
I'm trying to rely as much on the science as I can and what, you know, neuroscientists have seen
with brain scans of trans versus cisgendered people. That's fine. What are your views on this
whole rapid onset gender dysphoria? Well, the truth is that rapid onset gender dysphoria isn't
a new phenomenon. It's not recognized medically, and the thing is that the DSM and the W Path,
the World Professional Association and for transgender health standards of care,
have recognized that not all gender dysphoria starts at childhood. The W Path standards specifically
state many adolescents and adults presenting with gender dysphoria actually do not report a
history of childhood gender non-conforming behavior. Therefore, it may come as a surprise to others,
parents, family members, when a youth's gender dysphoria becomes first evident in adolescents,
and that's exactly what that specific study was describing. This, the researcher didn't actually
work with the kids themselves. She took a survey from parents who were describing what they were
observing in their kids. It wasn't coming from the kids themselves, and I think if you ask the kids
and you had someone who was working with those kids, you'd get a very different picture. So,
that's why I'm incredibly apprehensive to really give that study any sort of validity. Of course,
you can make great studies based on survey data, but the researcher has to be working specifically
with these parents and with these kids, which somebody like Christina Alton does. She does a lot
of the gender cognition study that I mentioned earlier. She did that, but she was working with
every single one of those kids. I think it's, no, it's not Lisa Marciano who did it. Oh, Lisa
Littman was the researcher who did the rapid onset gender dysphoria. She didn't, she never worked
a single day with any of those kids. So, I'm very apprehensive, and especially because she did
take people or recruit for the study from sites that already had an anti-transgender bias or parents
who already were apprehensive about accepting their kids. So, I question that. There's a little,
more nuance to that study, and I think there would be validity if she would work with the kids,
and that was the experience of the kids, but in this case, I just can't give it validity because
we've already described these experiences for decades in the W.P.A.T.S. TensorFlow of Care.
Well, don't you think it's interesting, though, and this is one of the things from the Littman study
about ROGD that I thought was interesting, that they, these parents reported that in for most of
them, I think it's something like, I can't find the exact one, but most of them reported
that their children in their child's peer groups, peer groups had at, you know, 50% of them were also
trans or identified as something like non-binary. Considering the overall population of trans
people in the United States, that seems like a huge over-representation. It definitely does seem
like that would kind of at least make me wonder. And if these children are, sorry, these teens
are reporting gender dysphoria and hadn't had any signs of or symptoms of it before, at least not
any documented ones that the parents could tell. And then not only are they now describing gender
dysphoria, but a lot of their friends are as well, doesn't that sort of make you wonder whether this
perhaps a phase which teens have been known to go through versus something that is persistent,
you know, over, let's say, 10 years, if it's just something that seems to have sprung up.
So again, there's nothing that's going to happen medically while they're under the age of consent
without that diagnosis. So you would still have to have it be insistent, consistent, and persistent
over at least a period of six months. So it's not like these kids are coming out and immediately
hormones the next day. That's a different that's. But I mean, I think a lot of people might believe
that six months is quite sure. And we're talking about six months before, specifically, hormones,
right, not surgery. Yeah, exactly. No, surgery. Usually somebody has to be monitored for at least
two years and you have to get two different letters. It's there's there's a lot more to surgery than
people people realize it's it's a lot more gate kept than than anything else. It's it's still to this
day. But as for the peer group, I just wanted to mention something regarding that. People don't
realize just how much because trans people have always been outsiders, how much when we find that
we don't get the acceptance, we we seek each other out. It's that's how we've been historically.
People think that, Oh, I may maybe seen one trans person, but the the problem is that
typically if you've seen one trans person, you've probably seen at least five because it's kind of
that joke we travel impacts. So I that's that's why I kind of question that. I don't know if these
kids have sought each other out or if they've always been friends and you know, all of a sudden,
all of them came out. There's a and the fact that it's a report of the parent and not the kid.
Again, makes me question it. So there's a lot more nuance for me to take that claim at its face value.
And I think ultimately what both of us would like is to see everybody, kids, whatever,
happy, healthy. And I'm kind of of the position that, you know, I know for someone who is trans
and an adult, it's very, I guess might be obvious for you to look back and say, man, I knew exactly
how I felt when I was younger. If I would have been able to transition sooner, then my life would
have been different. But I, you know, still for me, the the issue of trying to understand what is
happening in child in a child's mind is very hard. I am glad that it's not I'm a girl. Here you are
hormones and surgery. But I do think that even with something like a social transition, that there
may be, you know, emotional or psychological effects, if that is not actually what you will
later be identifying as and I'm sure as someone who's trans, you can understand how important even
things like being perceived as the gender you want are. So I think some of the people who brush off,
oh, it's it's just social. There's no medication yet. That is there is still weight to that, I think.
Yeah, and definitely it's it's always been recommended that while the person is
transitioning and even these kids, if they're going through a social transition and they think it
might be something that they're going to do in the future, they're being monitored consistently.
So they have psychological assessment, extensive psychological assessment to see, you know,
that's the reason that that's actually part of the reason for puberty blockers is to give them
more time to explore if there could be other things there without pushing the kid in any
specific direction, which is the point of affirmation therapy. It's not to move them toward
transition. It's to give the child a chance to explore and to kind of find out where they lie and
puberty blockers give that time social transition gives that time. It's definitely not something
like, okay, they're they're diagnosed and then we don't see them again until they're, you know,
they're 10 or 11. They're consistently monitored to mitigate any of those factors.
And this is kind of just the last thing that I want to touch on and it's not necessarily,
I guess it is part of the whole question we have seen cases in Canada specifically. And I think
some in the States as well, where parents have been at odds with things like court systems and,
you know, their children's, therapist, psychiatrist, psychologist, a whole slew of different medical
professionals, I think have been brought into this conversation where their child is wanting
to undergo hormone therapy and the parents do not want that. It's actually kind of being
established now that in some places that may be grounds for the child to be removed from their
parents custody. What are your opinions on that? I think it's it's a case by case basis. I think
there was one case here in the US in Ohio. I think it was a trans boy. And if you read what was going
on with that child, not even a child, I think he was 16 or 17 at the time when they put him with
his grandparents. His parents were basically telling him things like you're going to hell.
They were emotionally abusive to the point where he ended up on suicide watch and after an attempt
and this was going on over a while. So I think that's a case where it is definitely child abuse and
that's where at least legal professionals and the medical professionals in conjunction with the
legal professionals should come in. I think if it's just a case where there really is no,
there's nothing that medical professionals are observing to really have that concern. Maybe that
that might be a case to just kind of step back, but especially if the child is undergoing emotional
and maybe even physical abuse, they definitely need to be, you know, cared for in a different way.
Well, I think that's something that I would hope everybody would agree with that. Things like
emotional abuse, physical abuse, definitely telling your child that they're unwanted, unloved,
anything like that regardless of how they're behaving in terms of their gender is absolutely
unacceptable. But Julie, thank you so much for coming on, having this conversation. I hope the
people who are watching this have something new to think about. Maybe if people want to follow you,
what you're doing, where can they find you? Oh, I'm on Twitter, Julie Ray, J-U-L-I-E-R-E-I,
like the store not the pop star. So that's the easiest way to get ahold of me. You can check
out my stuff on IMDB whenever I have a new project or I have a new show that I'm on. I post
it there, but definitely Twitter. Come have a conversation and be nice. Please be nice to each
other. Definitely. Again, thank you so much. I'm so glad we could do this. Thanks Lauren. It's been a
pleasure.

text: Hey guys, welcome back to the show. Today we are going to be interviewing Julie Goldstein about the issue of trans children. Now if you've watched the show before you'll know that when it comes to trans kids, I just do not believe that children are old enough or mature enough to be able to do something like determine their own gender. Julie, however, disagrees with that and she actually reached out to me wanting to share her perspective. As an activist, Julie is extremely well informed about the procedures and guidelines that currently surround children transitioning. Regardless of how you or I might feel about trans children, it's important to remember that the views that Julie holds are now what's considered in many ways standard in Western medicine. In the medical, the psychiatric, the psychological community right now, Julie's views are considered mainstream. Honestly, a doctor is more likely to agree with her than with me. These are the opinions. These are the viewpoints, the mentality that we are dealing with and I think it is so important that we understand them. So with that being said, I am hugely thankful to Julie for being willing to come on here and talk about these issues which I know are controversial. In any case though, let's get on with the show. Hey Julie, thank you so much for coming on. Oh, thanks for having me Lauren. I really appreciate it. Yeah, no problem. So you've actually been on Stephen Crowder's show before and I think a lot of people who saw that episode really enjoyed it, really enjoyed the conversation for people who maybe missed out on that and aren't familiar with you, would you mind I guess giving a bit of your background, your interests are that kind of thing? Sure, I'm an actress and voice over artist, but I'm also a trans rights activist. I think what distinguishes me from other people is I kind of like to talk to people about the data and I like to get other points of view. I've never been on one of those people who's uncomfortable hearing a different point of view. So it's easier to have conversations that way across the aisle, which I don't think a lot of us are having anymore. And I think that's that's so great and that's why I'm so happy to have you here today. What I was hoping we could talk about was specifically the issue of trans children. That's something we've talked a lot about on my show. People who have watched my episodes before know that when it comes to the issue of transitioning and gender, I do think that you know, five, six, seven year olds, these children, these children aren't able to maybe grasp all the complexities and nuance that revolve around gender. I know that's not the point of view you have. And so I was hoping that we could talk about that for people who maybe missed out on your conversation with Crowder because I think you guys did touch upon this when he had you on. What are your views to that? Transitioning and children, do you support it? Yes or no? And is there an age where you think that a child would be too young to be able to self identify their own gender?
